text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmits revised IRM 8.22.4, Collection Due Process, Collection Due Process Appeals Program. This revision incorporates from Appeals Interim Guidance memorandum AP-08-0520-0005, Reissuance of Interim Guidance for Paperless Collection Due Process (CDP) Case Work Received from Automated Collection System Support (ACSS), and includes guidance not originally intended to be incorporated into the IRM.
See the table below for material changes in this IRM:

Title and Brief Description 8.22.4.1,ProgramScopeandObjectives Revised this section to agree with current Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Research (SPDER) guidelines. 8.22.4.2.3,StatuteRe-sponsibilityinCDP At (1) and (3), rephrased to clarify that Appeals has no responsibility to protect a collection statute from expira- tion, or to prepare Form 3999, Statute Expiration Report, when a collection statute expires. 8.22.4.2.5,AttachCertainDocumentstoACDS At (3), added: Message ﬁles from taxpayer digital com- munications (TDC). 8.22.4.2.6,DestructionofPaperDocuments Incorporates from Appeals Interim Guidance memoran- dum AP-08-0520-0005, Reissuance of Interim Guidance for Paperless Collection Due Process (CDP) Case Work Received from Automated Collection System Support (ACSS). New section added discuss- ing when to destroy a paper document after having scanned and digitally attached the document to ACDS. 8.22.4.2.7,RetainRelatedPaperFilesWhen closing Incorporates from Appeals Interim Guidance memoran- dum AP-08-0520-0005, Reissuance of Interim Guidance for Paperless Collection Due Process (CDP) Case Work Received from Automated Collection System Support (ACSS). New section added to address the retention of paper case ﬁles. 8.22.4.3,EquivalentHearing (EH) At (4), clariﬁed that levy is generally suspended during an EH, as a matter of policy.
Incorporates from Appeals Interim Guidance memoran- dum AP-

, Reissuance of Interim Guidance for Paperless Collection Due Process (CDP) Case Work Received from Automated Collection System Support (ACSS). New section added discuss- ing when to destroy a paper document after having scanned and digitally attached the document to ACDS.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 8.22.4, dated August 26, 2020, is superseded. This revision incorporates from Appeals Interim Guidance memorandum AP-08-0520-0005, Reissuance of Interim Guidance for Paperless Collection Due Process (CDP) Case Work Received from Automated Collection System Support (ACSS), and includes guidance not originally intended to be incorporated into the IRM.
AUDIENCE
Appeals Officers, Appeals Account Resolution Specialists and Appeals Team Managers

) The Tax Court’s standard of review for non-liability CDP determinations is for abuse of discretion. The Tax Court considers: • Whether Appeals’ factual and legal conclusions reached at a CDP hearing are reasonable, not whether they are best possible or indisput- able • The reasonableness of Appeals’ ultimate decision In Dalton v. Commissioner ,
F.
d
, the First Circuit held that a deferen- tial standard of review is appropriate, noting the record usually available to Tax Court in CDP cases. (

) CDP ﬁles sent to Appeals should contain sufficient documentation for Appeals to make a determination. Due to statutory requirements, if a CDP ﬁle lacks documentation, it cannot be returned to Collection as a premature referral. Instead, the hearing officer must decide whether to: • Request relevant information from the taxpayer, or • Issue an Appeals Referral Investigation (ARI) for Collection to secure verify information (
) Part
Collection Process IRM contains the primary administrative policies procedures for considering alternatives to collection and case resolutions such as: • Offer in Compromise - IRM

• Financial Analysis - IRM
• Currently Not Collectible - IRM
• Liability Collection, Balance Due - IRM
for Automated Collection Service (ACS) cases. (

, in general, to: • Verify whether administrative procedures were followed in issuing a Notice of Intent to Levy and/or ﬁling a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) • Review Collection case actions and decisions, taking into account any special circumstances • Evaluate any offers of collection alternatives by the taxpayer (

to take or propose any enforcement or investigative activity do not apply to Appeals employees. (

) IRC
requires the IRS to notify the taxpayer of the ﬁling of a Notice of Federal Tax Lien (NFTL) and the right to request a CDP lien hearing within
business days after the ﬁrst NFTL for a tax period is ﬁled. (
) IRC
requires the IRS to notify the taxpayer of the right to request a CDP hearing not less than
days before issuing the ﬁrst levy to collect a tax period. Note: The IRS waits
days after issuing the notice of assessment of tax and demand for payment before issuing the Notice of Intent to Levy. However, Treas. Reg.
) permits concurrent issuance of the notice of assessment and the Notice of Intent to Levy. (
) IRC

(f) contains exceptions to a right to a hearing before levy. When a levy is served in the following instances, the taxpayer is offered an opportunity to request a post-levy hearing: a. Collection of the tax was in jeopardy b. State Income Tax Levy Program (SITLP) c. “Disqualiﬁed” employment tax levy (DETL) d. Federal contractor levies under the Federal Payment Levy Program (FPLP) (
) IRC
and IRC

provide for one hearing per type of tax and tax period for the tax debt listed on the NFTL or Notice of Intent to Levy. The right to request a CDP hearing applies to the ﬁrst NFTL ﬁled or the ﬁrst levy notice issued for a particular tax debt. Example: IRS ﬁled an NFTL in Washington County on
listing a Form
tax debt for tax year

tax debt. The NFTL ﬁled
in Washington County is the NFTL to which the

) The taxpayer may receive more than one CDP pre-levy hearing under IRC

where the same type of tax for the same period is involved, but where the amount of the unpaid tax has changed as a result of an additional assess- ment of tax (not including interest or penalties) for that period or an additional accuracy-related or ﬁling-delinquency penalty has been assessed. Note: Collection cannot systemically isolate an additional assessment of tax when issuing the CDP levy notice. A CDP levy notice for additional tax includes balance for the whole period. If the taxpayer requests a CDP hearing, the hearing only covers the additional tax assessment if the taxpayer already had an opportunity for a hearing on the original tax assessment. (
) The taxpayer is not entitled to another CDP hearing under IRC

if the ditional assessment represents accruals of interest, penalties, or both. However, an exception to one hearing per type of tax and tax period can with penalties. The taxpayer is entitled to a second CDP notice/second oppor- tunity for a hearing for Failure to Pay (FTP) penalty if the prior CDP notice listed no accrued or assessed FTP. See Treas. Reg.

) IRC
refers to IRC
for the legal requirements regarding: • Matters considered by Appeals at the hearing- IRC
(c) • Judicial review of the determination made by Appeals-IRC
(d) • Suspension of collection activity and the statutory period of limitations- IRC

) A CDP lien hearing is held in conjunction with a CDP levy hearing whenever an NFTL is ﬁled and Notice of Intent to Levy are concurrently issued, and the taxpayer requests a hearing under both Code sections. (
) In making a CDP determination, IRC

) requires Appeals to: a. Verify applicable law and administrative procedure were met; b. Consider relevant issues relating to the unpaid tax, the ﬁling of the NFTL or the proposed levy; and c. Consider whether the action taken or proposed balances the govern- ment’s need for the efficient collection of taxes with the taxpayer’s legitimate concern that any collection action be no more intrusive than necessary. (
) The taxpayer may raise any non-frivolous issue relating to the NFTL or the proposed levy. (
) An issue may not be raised at the CDP lien or levy hearing if the taxpayer

a. Verify applicable law and administrative procedure were met; b. Consider relevant issues relating to the unpaid tax, the ﬁling of the NFTL or the proposed levy; and c. Consider whether the action taken or proposed balances the govern
ment’s need for the efficient collection of taxes with the taxpayer’s legitimate concern that any collection action be no more intrusive than necessary.
) The taxpayer may raise any non-frivolous issue relating to the NFTL or the proposed levy. (

) An issue may not be raised at the CDP lien or levy hearing if the taxpayer par- ticipated meaningfully in any previous administrative or judicial proceeding where the same issue was already raised and considered. (
) The taxpayer may seek judicial review of the Notice of Determination by ﬁling petition in the United States Tax Court. in (
) In CDP, Appeals has no responsibility to protect a collection statute from expi- ration. (
) Appeals has no requirement in CDP to prepare a Form
, Statute Expira- tion Report, for expired collection statutes.

) The use of digital signatures in taxpayer correspondence is commonplace. When digitally signing any document being sent to the taxpayer or representa- tive, the signature must be only a scanned facsimile of your actual signature. (
) Signatures must not include Adobe graphics, the date, SEID, e-mail address or other employee information or be merely a typewritten signature font. (
) Contact Appeals BSP, the lead program analyst for CDP, or the Appeals Exchange web site for assistance creating digital signatures. (

) Regardless of how the CDP case ﬁle is managed (as a paper ﬁle, electronic, or a hybrid of the two), certain key documents should always be attached elec- tronically to the ACDS record. This will ensure the secure storage and ease availability of these key documents. (
) Documents should be attached electronically to the ACDS record for the CDP key ﬁle. (

) These documents include the following: • Appeals Case Memorandum or NOD Attachment • Counsel Memorandums • Notice of Determination or Decision Letter • Message ﬁles from Taxpayer Digital Communications (TDC) • Written veriﬁcation of IRC

) See Exhibit
, CDP Naming Conventions for Documents Attached ACDS, for appropriate ﬁle naming conventions for certain uploaded documents.
) Destruction of Paper Documents (
) Appeals manages an increasing number of Collection Due Process cases electronic means. This process renders most paper documents obsolete they have been scanned and uploaded to ACDS. (

) For cases that are managed electronically or as a paper/electronic hybrid, the following steps for scanned documents: • Scan the paper document • Review the scanned document to ensure it is legible and matches paper original • Save the scanned document to a destination on your computer, using appropriate naming conventions. For naming conventions, see Exhibit

, CDP Naming Conventions for Documents Attached to ACDS • Upload the ﬁle to ACDS • Conﬁrm the upload attached to ACDS • Destroy the paper documents once attachment to ACDS has been conﬁrmed Note: See also (
) below. (

) For cases managed by fully electronic means, be sure to retain electronically in ACDS all documents you reviewed in making your determination. Such documentation is necessary to frame the complete basis of your decision, which is critical in the event a case needs to be defended in Tax Court. See IRM
for details pertaining to the content of the administrative record. (

) Documents that require an original signature should be retained but also attached to the electronic record in ACDS. At closing, following existing dures, any documents that require an original signature should be forwarded by APS to the appropriate compliance function monitoring section that will monitor the agreement.
) Related Paper When Closing (

) Retain with the CDP case any related work unit (WUNO) or other paper that were used in making your determination. If a Notice of Determination (NOD) is issued, these related paper ﬁles should be suspended along with CDP administrative ﬁle, whether the CDP was managed as a paper ﬁle, electronically, or as a paper and electronic hybrid. For more information, IRM
, CDP Notices of Determination (NOD), and IRM
, ministrative Record.
) Equivalent Hearing (EH) (

) A taxpayer who fails to make a timely request for a CDP hearing is not to a CDP hearing, but may request an administrative Appeals hearing, which referred to as an Equivalent Hearing (EH). In an EH, follow the same proce- dures and consider the same issues as a CDP hearing. (

) A taxpayer must submit a written request for an EH within the one-year beginning the day after the date of the CDP levy notice. For a CDP lien EH, taxpayer must submit a written request for the EH within the one-year period beginning the day after the end of the ﬁve-business-day period following
Collection Due Process Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Collection Due Process Appeals Program 8.22.4
ﬁling of the NFTL. If a taxpayer does not request an EH within the prescribed time, the taxpayer forgoes the right to an EH. (
) Appeals conﬁrms a request for an EH was not timely in the CDP separate timeliness determination (CDPTD). See IRM
, Collection Due Process Timeliness Determinations (CDPTD). (
) During an EH, levy action is generally suspended as a matter of policy: • On tax periods not subject to a CDP levy hearing, unless all pre-levy notiﬁcations have been met or the section
(d) notice has been given and one of the exceptions in
(f) applies, • On tax periods subject to the EH • On tax periods subject to a CDP NFTL hearing for which all pre-levy notiﬁcations have been met Note: Because the statutory period under IRC
(e) is not suspended during EH, Collection may determine it to be necessary to levy despite the above factors. IRM
) below describes when Collection may deem it propriate to levy while an EH case is open. (

) Appeals issues a Decision Letter instead of a Notice of Determination. The taxpayer is not entitled to seek judicial review of Appeals’ decision in an EH case unless one or more of the following issues are raised: a. Spousal relief under IRC
b. Abatement of interest under IRC
(h) c. Timeliness of the request for a CDP hearing (
) There is no retained jurisdiction in an EH case. (
) See Treas. Reg.
(i) for more information on EH hearings. (

) Collection should only issue one CDP levy notice and one CDP lien notice tax period, unless an additional amount of tax (other than interest and penalty accruals) is assessed. Process Appeals Program
page
ﬁling of the NFTL. If a taxpayer does not request an EH within the prescribed time, the taxpayer forgoes the right to an EH.
Exception: Collection must issue separate CDP notices to husband and wife when the liabilities are joint, even if they reside at the same address
Exception: Collection may issue separate CDP notices to individual partners as well as the partnership entity in partnerships

) Once a Form
, Request for a Collection Due Process or Equivalent Hearing, is received from a taxpayer, Collection may continue to work with the taxpayer for up to
days, if the taxpayer is willing. If Collection determines there are indicators of fraud, Collection may hold a CDP hearing request for
days while developing a fraud referral. See IRM 5.1.9.3.3, Processing CDP and EH Requests. Collection promptly forwards a case to Appeals in the following instances:

following instances: a. Frivolous issues are raised b. The taxpayer only wants to work with Appeals c. The taxpayer is not seeking to resolve the issue but is using the CDP process as a method for delay, i.e., pyramiding in-business trust fund taxpayer d. ) The CSED is systemically calculated and updated via the TC
and TC entries. An exception to this systemic CSED update is an IMF account involving a joint income tax liability where only one spouse has requested hearing. (
) The CSED is not suspended during an EH case, so a TC
AC
is entered onto each EH tax period. (

) IRS uses Automated Levy Programs (ALPs) through which select federal tax debts are matched with state taxing authorities and federal agencies disbursing funds, such as salary, pension, and vendor payments. See IRM
, Automated Levy Programs (ACS), and IRM
, Automated Levy Programs (Collection ﬁeld) for more information about ALPs and the procedures used administer the programs, which are divided into three categories:

administer the programs, which are divided into three categories: • Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend Levy Program (AKPFD) – attaches the Permanent Fund Dividend distributed by Alaska • Federal Payment Levy Program (FPLP) – attaches federal payments individuals or businesses • Municipal Tax Levy Program (MTLP) - matches a Master File database of delinquent taxpayers eligible to be levied against a database of income tax refunds for each municipality participating in MTLP • State Income Tax Levy Program (SITLP) – attaches state income refund The following TC
action codes identify ALPs and may appear in either CDP or EH cases: TC

): Paragraph (f)(

) of this section shall not prohibit levy if the taxpayer ﬁles a written notice with the IRS that waives the restriction on levy imposed by this section, the IRS determines that the proposed installment agreement was submitted solely to delay collection, or the IRS determines that collection of the tax to which the installment agreement or proposed installment agreement relates is in jeopardy. Offer in Com- promise Treas. Reg.
): The IRS may levy to collect the liability that is the subject of an offer to compromise during the period the IRS is evaluating whether that
in jeopardy. Com- Treas. Reg.

): The IRS may levy to collect the liability that is the subject of an offer to compromise during the period the IRS is evaluating whether that offer will be accepted if it determines that collection of the liability is in jeopardy. (

) Collection of the tax by levy is generally suspended on tax periods that are subject of: • An EH • Timely-ﬁled request for a CDP lien hearing if all pre-levy requirements are met • During a retained jurisdiction proceeding (

) Collection may deem levy action appropriate in a CDP lien or EH case if: a. Collection is at risk, e.g., the taxpayer is dissipating assets or pyramiding additional liabilities b. The taxpayer raises only frivolous issues c. The taxpayer is requesting an installment agreement or offer in compro- mise solely to delay the collection process (

) In such instances, Collection contacts the hearing officer’s Appeals Team Manager (ATM) by secure e-mail to advise levy action is planned and asks whether Appeals has information that may affect the decision to levy. The responds within

days with yes or no response: • Yes, Appeals has information that levy would create an economic hardship for an individual taxpayer, or • Yes, Appeals has information that would prohibit levy absent a determi- nation that collection of the tax is in jeopardy, or • No, Appeals has no information that would prohibit levy action (

) Collection may ﬁle an NFTL while a CDP lien or levy hearing is pending. Before doing so, they contact the ATM to advise of the planned action and see if Appeals has any information that would affect the NFTL ﬁling decision. (
) Collection cannot include an Affordable Care Act (ACA) individual shared re- sponsibility payment (SRP) MFT
liability on an NFTL or proposed levy. As result, MFT
periods should never be in CDP. Employees in (

) The issues for which the taxpayer requests Appeals consideration guide who Appeals considers such issues. See IRM 8.20.5, Carding New Receipts, and IRM 8.20.7, Closing Procedures, for APS processing of CDP and EH cases.
The AARS may document the receipt of a case for screening and corrective actions taken. Veriﬁcation actions during the screening process include:
AARS may request a withdrawal of the CDP hearing using Letter 4388, With- drawal Solicitation. See IRM 8.22.5.2.5, CDP Withdrawals.
The Fresno AARS team provides Customer Service on closed cases. The following are examples of problems that AARS can resolve:

ATMs generally have supervisory responsibilities for Appeals Officers and Appeals Account Resolution Specialists (AARS). ATMs review cases for com- pleteness, accuracy and decision quality. ATMs have approval authority in most CDP cases. See Exhibit 8.22.4-1, Delegation Order Appeals-193-1.

) The objective of Fast Track Mediation (FTM) is to allow SB/SE Collection personnel and SB/SE taxpayers an opportunity to mediate their collection disputes with an Appeals official serving as a neutral party, or mediator. FTM is optional for the taxpayer and does not eliminate or replace existing dispute resolution options, including the taxpayer’s opportunity to request a hearing before Appeals. For guidance on FTM, see IRM
, Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR) Program, Fast Track Mediation for Collection Cases.

Form/Letter Number and Name Purpose Form 12256 : Withdrawal of Request for Collection Due Process or Equivalent Hearing Taxpayer withdraws from either CDP or EH. Form 12257 : Summary Notice of Determination and Waiver of Judicial Review Taxpayer agrees with the resolution reached with Appeals and waives the right to judicial review. Form 14041 : Waiver of Right to Request New AO/SO Taxpayer waives the prior involvement of an Appeals employee, allowing them to conduct the current hearing. Letter 4382 : Form 12257 Closing Letter Transmits the waiver Form 12257 to taxpayer. Letter 4388 : Withdrawal Solicitation Solicits withdrawal where Collection resolved the taxpayer’s issue.

Common Terms and Acronyms Used in Collection Due Process

AARS Appeals Account Resolution Specialist ABINT Interest Abatement ACA Affordable Care Act ACDS Appeals Centralized Database System ACM Appeals Case Memorandum ADR Alternative Dispute Resolution AKPFD Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend (Levy Program) AO Appeals Officer (may refer to a Collection AO or Exam AO AOIC Automated Offer-in-Compromise (system) APGOLF Appeals Generator of Letters and Forms. APGOLF and APGOLF 2.0, are subsystems of ACDS, and contain a compilation of most of the letters and forms used by Appeals employees. APS Account and Processing Support, the unit respon- sible for the administrative processing of cases in Appeals. AQMS Appeals Quality Measurement System ARI Appeals Referral Investigation ATE Appeals Technical Employee is an umbrella term used to refer generally to any Appeals employee who is assigned a case for settlement consider- ation (generally, an Exam AO, Collection AO or AARS).
